awd_titl_txt: SG: Collaborative Research: The evolution of extreme phenotypic convergence across fish lineages in the hyper-diverse lower Congo River
awd_abstract_narration:
The lower Congo River is one of the most extreme freshwater habitats on Earth, with some of the planet's largest whitewater rapids and deepest underwater canyons. These rapids, eddies and canyons are home to an extraordinary array of fishes, many of which are striking in appearance and exhibit numerous adaptations to life in turbulent, high-energy waters. In such extreme habitats, evolution sometimes produces independently derived yet remarkably similar traits. For example, many distantly related fishes in the lower Congo have independently lost body coloration, have reduced or absent eyes, and share similar elongate body shapes and modified sensory features. How and when did these unusual features evolve? These striking examples of convergence (when similar traits evolve independently) strongly suggest a shared signature of selection, likely in response to the extraordinary hydrology of the river itself. This research project will examine the phylogenetic and morphological basis of convergence in the lower Congo fish fauna to address fundamental questions about the mechanisms that promote adaptation and diversification in extreme environments. These analyses will provide new insights into how limbs are reduced or lost in diverse fish lineages that can then be applied more broadly to other vertebrates.  U.S. undergraduate students from a minority-serving, principally undergraduate institution will receive broad training in tropical field studies, molecular systematics, and African biodiversity more generally. Findings from the study will be incorporated within both graduate and undergraduate courses, and results will be disseminated more broadly by a Science Explorations video and project website.  Other data will be deposited in online, open-access repositories.
 
This study investigates a newly discovered system of complex in situ phenotypic convergence among members of phylogenetically diverse fish lineages. Two major datasets will be generated and integrated: 1) a phylogenetic framework based on ultra-conserved elements to determine the topology and temporal framework of within-clade divergences; and 2) a detailed morphological characterization of within-group convergence utilizing a range of quantification and visualization techniques, including 3-dimensional computed tomography (3D CT) reconstruction, histology, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and multivariate morphometric approaches. Using these datasets, the study will investigate how rapidly these phenotypes arose, morphological correspondence of convergence within and between clades, and whether multiple traits evolved in concert. By conducting in-depth, foundational phylogenetic, anatomical, and morphometric analyses of this unparalleled natural experiment, the study will potentially transform understanding of the variety of mechanisms by which convergent phenotypes have repeatedly evolved across deep phylogenetic time. This research will also generate a broadly useful resource for future comparative studies with similar convergent systems (e.g. Astyanax cavefishes) and will establish the foundation for determining the genomic basis of these phenotypes.

por.por_cntn:
How does evolution produce the incredible biodiversity that supports our planet? And how does it generate similar (convergent) forms across very distinct groups of living things? Our project investigated these questions, using as a case study the extraordinary diversity and adaptations of fishes in the lower Congo River (LCR). The LCR is one of the most extreme freshwater habitats on Earth and vast volumes of its waters flow down a short (350 km) narrow channel to the Atlantic Ocean, on the way forming some of the largest whitewater rapids and deepest underwater canyons found anywhere on the planet. Despite only occupying 2% of the area of central Africa's huge Congo basin, the LCR is home to over 30% of all Congolese fishes, and many of those are found only in the LCR making this short stretch of river a continental hotspot of freshwater fish biodiversity.

 

Not only is the river home to hundreds of species, but many of them are also bizarre in appearance and show adaptations to life in turbulent, high-energy waters. Among these are striking examples of convergent evolution (where separate species undergoing similar selective pressures evolve to exhibit often strikingly similar morphological traits). In the LCR, fish species from six unrelated families have independently lost pigmentation and eyes/visual acuity and share a range of other features usually associated with cave-dwelling fishes. But unlike still-water cave habitats, in LCR habitats this convergence (which we term cryptophthalmia) strongly suggests a shared signature of selection to an extreme and highly dynamic riverine system.

 

Our study found that the LCR presents an unparalleled natural experiment to investigate the variety of mechanisms by which populations evolve, species arise, and convergent phenotypes have repeatedly evolved across deep phylogenetic time. In a multi-disciplinary approach incorporating molecular (genomic) and morphological techniques we determined the phylogenetic relationships of many LCR species showing that much of the diversity in this hotspot was generated by past hydrological events driven by climatic changes. We also investigated the genes that may underlie the loss of eyes and pigment, as well as genes involved in slower metabolism (often associated with dark, nutrient-poor environments). These findings have relevance for understanding genomic mechanisms in humans correlated with loss of visual acuity and metabolic disorders and help us better understand how extreme environments can drive rapid evolution.

 

The project has engaged, supported, and provided training for students from across the academic spectrum from high school interns, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows in the US and in the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Republic of Congo, with most US students having come from underrepresented backgrounds. Our project has provided opportunities for both US and Congolese students to participate in international fieldwork and hands-on research, and as part of our educational goals, we have developed a teaching module on evolutionary convergence, focused on the LCR system, and this has been implemented in undergraduate classes at two minority serving institutions in the US. During a 3-day project workshop held at the University of Kinshasa and attended by students from universities from across the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Republic of Congo, the students participated in developing a Facebook webpage - Congo Ichthyology Group (CIG), and this site continues to serve as a communication channel for African and international students studying Congolese fishes.
